ud8.6:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Magadhans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at the village of Pāṭali.
ud8.6:1.3: The lay followers of Pāṭali Village heard that he had arrived.
ud8.6:1.5: So they went to see him, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
ud8.6:1.7: “Sir, please consent to come to our guest house.”
ud8.6:2.1: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, the lay followers of Pāṭali Village got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went to the guest house, where they spread carpets all over, prepared seats, set up a water jar, and placed a lamp. Then they went back to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and told him of their preparations, saying:
ud8.6:3.1: In the morning, the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the guest house together with the Saṅgha of mendicants. Having washed his feet he entered the guest house and sat against the central column facing east.
ud8.6:3.2: The Saṅgha of mendicants also washed their feet, entered the guest house, and sat against the west wall facing east, with the Buddha right in front of them.
ud8.6:3.3: The lay followers of Pāṭali Village also washed their feet, entered the guest house, and sat against the east wall facing west, with the Buddha right in front of them.
ud8.6:4.1: “Householders, there are these five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.
ud8.6:4.3: Firstly, an unethical person loses substantial wealth on account of negligence.
ud8.6:5.1: Furthermore, an unethical person gets a bad reputation.
ud8.6:6.1: Furthermore, an unethical person enters any kind of assembly timid and embarrassed, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
ud8.6:7.1: Furthermore, an unethical person dies feeling lost.
ud8.6:8.1: Furthermore, an unethical person, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ud8.6:8.3: These are the five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.
ud8.6:9.1: There are these five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.
ud8.6:9.3: Firstly, an ethical person gains substantial wealth on account of diligence.
ud8.6:10.1: Furthermore, an ethical person gets a good reputation.
ud8.6:11.1: Furthermore, an ethical person enters any kind of assembly bold and self-assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
ud8.6:12.1: Furthermore, an ethical person dies not feeling lost.
ud8.6:13.1: Furthermore, when an ethical person’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ud8.6:13.3: These are the five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.”
ud8.6:14.1: The Buddha spent most of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the lay followers of Pāṭali Village with a Dhamma talk. Then he dismissed them,
ud8.6:14.2: “The night is getting late, householders. Please go at your convenience.”
ud8.6:14.3: And then the lay followers of Pāṭali Village approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
ud8.6:14.5: Soon after they left the Buddha entered a private cubicle.
ud8.6:15.1: Now at that time the Magadhan ministers Sunidha and Vassakāra were building a citadel at Pāṭali Village to keep the Vajjis out.
ud8.6:15.2: At that time thousands of deities were taking possession of building sites in Pāṭali Village.
ud8.6:15.3: Illustrious rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by illustrious deities.
ud8.6:15.4: Middling rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by middling deities.
